node.text:
China's growing ranks of rural entrepreneurs are getting rich peddling their produce on social media. 

One of the scene's stars is Jin Guowei, aka Brother Pomegranate — an internet sensation with 7.3 million followers and 300 million yuan ($46 million) of sales in 2020. (video via @quicktake)

node.title: Livestreaming Farmers Earn Millions From Fruit on China’s TikTok

node.text:
In almost every way measurable, millennials in the U.S. at 40 are doing worse financially than the generations that came before them.

Fewer millennials own homes than their parents did at their age. They have more debt — especially student debt. They simply aren’t as wealthy. 

Now, if predictions of a long, post-Covid economic boom are to be believed, this may be the last opportunity an entire generation has to build wealth before heading off into retirement.

node.title: Millennials Are Running Out of Time to Build Wealth to Retire

node.text: When employees at software company 10Pines want a raise, they pitch their co-workers, not their boss. Here's what happens when a firm uses "radical transparency" to attract and retain talent.

node.title: Would You Let Your Colleagues Decide Your Salary?

node.text:
While the "15-minute city" model promotes neighborhood-level urban planning, Sweden is pursuing a hyper-local twist: a scheme to redesign every street in the nation.

For more, read the report by @citylab: bloomberg.com/citylab/design

node.text:
Two of the world's wealthiest individuals will attempt to fly into space just nine days apart.

Here's how their space trips compare. (via @quicktake)

node.text: The sudden cancellation of Ant Group’s IPO shocked investors, but Beijing's slapdown of Jack Ma was years in the making. And Alibaba and Ant aren't the only tech firms under scrutiny by Chinese regulators.

node.title: How China Lost Patience With Its Loudest Billionaire

node.text:
Plant-based meat used to mean burgers and sausages. Not anymore.

Using techniques from 3D printing to specially cultivated mushrooms, these companies are at the forefront of the next generation of alternative meats: whole cuts. (via @quicktake)

node.text:
Taiwan is becoming a bigger issue between the world's two biggest superpowers. Taipei — a U.S. ally — and Beijing have avoided war for more than seven decades, but that balance is getting harder to maintain as China becomes more assertive in its desire for reunification.

Watch the full video at the link in bio to understand why analysts say Taiwan's status is "the most likely issue to draw China and the U.S. into a direct military conflict."

node.title: Why the Biggest U.S.-China Issue Is About Taiwan

node.text:
Shotgun houses are as much a hallmark of New Orleans as brass bands or beignets. Here's a short history of these famous U.S. homes built without hallways.

Explore more iconic home designs that shaped global cities in this @citylab series: bloomberg.com/home-design-history

node.title: Inside the History of New Orleans' Shotgun Houses

node.text:
Robinhood's public debut wasn't exactly "to the moon" Thursday.

Shortly after opening on the Nasdaq shares slid as much as 11%, but CEO Vlad Tenev says the company is focused on the future, not retail trading volatility.

He told @BloombergTV's @emilychangtv that the future of the company is in more investing options, including expanding its cryptocurrency offerings.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on July 29, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, beard, people standing, footwear, outdoors and text that says '7 Robinhood's co-founders are officially billionaires Bloomberg Wealth'.

node.text:
The stock market debut of Robinhood — whose app drew a new generation of investors into trading on their phones — has cemented its co-founders' spots among America's super-rich. 

Vlad Tenev, 34, and Baiju Bhatt, who's 36, released the first iteration of their app around eight years ago. With Robinhood shares at $38 apiece, CEO Tenev is worth about $2.4 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. Bhatt, who shared CEO duties until last year, has a net worth around $2.8 billion. 

Robinhood's IPO marks the pinnacle of a journey that’s helped usher in an era of no-fee stock trading and attracted the scrutiny of regulators. Read in full via the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on July 29, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Nikola founder Trevor Miltonis charged with misleading investors Bloomberg'.

node.text:
The founder and former chairman of Nikola has been charged with making false statements to backers of the electric-vehicle startup.

Trevor Milton, who stepped down from the Tesla competitor last year, is in federal custody after voluntarily surrendering. He's charged with misleading investors from November 2019 until around September 2020 about the development of Nikola’s products and technology. 

The company's shares fell the most in almost five months after the indictment was unsealed. Since June last year, its market cap has plunged from almost $29 billion to about $5 billion. Read the full story via the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on July 29, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Nigerian influencer Hushpuppi admits role in $1.1 million scam HUSHPUPPI 8 78 Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Ramon Olorunwa Abbas, known as @hushpuppi and the Billionaire Gucci Master to his followers, has admitted being part of a ploy to steal more than $1 million from a businessman attempting to finance a school project in Qatar.

Abbas's Instagram presence depicted a lavish lifestyle that helped turn him into a celebrity, posing for photos alongside pop stars and Premier League players.

According to U.S. prosecutors, the 37-year-old has taken part in scams that resulted in a total of $24 million in losses to the victims. Full story at the link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on July 29, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Tencent is now the world's worst stock bet after a $170 billion wipeout 開 BGI-S Va TENCENT Bloomberg'.

node.text:
China's unprecedented crackdown on its technology industry has turned Tencent from a market darling into the world’s biggest stock loser this month.

The Chinese Internet giant had tumbled 23% in July as of Wednesday, set for its worst month ever, erasing about $170 billion of market value. That marks the fastest evaporation of shareholder wealth worldwide during this period.

Nine of the top 10 losers in shareholder value this month are Chinese companies. Tap the link in bio to read more about the selloff.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on July 28, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Americans hesitant to bevaccinated are now lining up June 22 CUACr concer loomberg'.

node.text:
After months of slowing vaccination rates, the rise of the delta variant has more Americans seeking out a shot. 

Some of the most vaccine-resistant parts of the U.S. are now leading the country in the number of people getting a first dose. 

The highest daily rate of shots happening in places like Louisiana, Arkansas and Missouri — states that have had some of the lowest rates in the eight months since vaccines became available. 

Read more at the link in our bio.

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on July 28, 2021. May be an image of text.

node.text:
In a sign of the seriousness of the rising delta outbreak, Apple plans to restore a mask requirement at most of its U.S. retail stores for both customers and staff, even those who are vaccinated. 

Apple already started requiring masks for employees at select stores earlier this month, and it pushed back a return-to-office deadline for corporate employees. It also began requiring masks for customers in a few counties based on local guidelines. The decision was spurred by rising cases, new local mandates and CDC guidelines. 

Read more at the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on July 28, 2021. May be an image of balloon and text that says '"Dip-buying army" of day traders seizes on China drop IN@Alibaba Bloomberg'.

node.text:
As Beijing’s crackdown on corporate China roiled Wall Street, the Robinhood-powered cohort of day traders once again bought the dip.

Days after backstopping U.S. stocks with record equity purchases, retail investors plowed almost $1.7 billion into the market on Tuesday, according to Vanda Research. The firm says they sunk their millions into exchange-traded funds, including technology stocks. Find out more at the link in bio.

node.text:
Shonda Rhimes is one of the most powerful people in Hollywood with hit shows to her name including Bridgerton, Scandal and Grey’s Anatomy. 

David Rubenstein sat down with her for a long conversation about her production company, surprise move from ABC to Netflix and what the past year has been like with political and social upheaval.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on July 28, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, suit and text that says 'Tom Barrack's protege, 27, faces loyalty test over UAElinks links Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Working for Tom Barrack took Matthew Grimes to some exciting places — from private planes to international destinations to partying at the inauguration of former President Donald Trump.

That glittering life came to a halt when Grimes was arrested on July 20, hours after his former boss was detained. On Monday they appeared in a Brooklyn courtroom, pleading not guilty to charges that include acting as unregistered foreign agents trying to influence U.S. policy on behalf of the United Arab Emirates.

Barrack, an ally of Trump, had a habit of prizing loyalty and personal ties over experience when it came to hiring and promotion. Now Grimes’s allegiance to his mentor will be put to the test, as federal prosecutors are likely to push him to make a cooperation deal and testify against Barrack. Full story at the link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business in Longyearbyen. May be an image of 1 person, sitting, outdoors and text that says 'Norway unseats the U.S. as the best place tobe during Covid 11 Bloomberg'.

node.text:
The U.S.'s reign as the best place to be in the Covid-19 era was short-lived. Enter, Norway.

The Nordic country is the new No. 1 in Bloomberg’s Covid Resilience Ranking, with enough shots administered to cover almost half its population, near-zero fatalities and unsealed borders. The U.S., meanwhile, has seen vaccinations plateau and cases rise, though deaths remain a fraction of what they were in previous waves.

Norway is one of several European nations that have caught up, or even overtaken, the U.S. on key metrics like inoculation rates and the pace of reopening. Tap the link in bio to see how other countries rank in our Covid Resilience Tracker.

📷:: Sean Gallup/Getty Images
